cards.title: Lock down your aerial! / London's 1980s pirate radio scene

item.title: Lock down your aerial! London's 1980s pirate radio scene
item.trailText: Skip back to the time when towerblock studios, parties, zines and even an illegal television station fuelled UK bass culture. Believe!
item.standFirst:
Out to the 80s pirate radio massive ... from B-boys to dub fanatics, Kiss FM’s early days to crate-digging in Groove Records, skip back to the time when towerblock studios, parties, zines and even an illegal television station fuelled UK bass culture. Believe!

  • Shout Out! UK Pirate Radio in the 1980s is at the ICA, London SW1Y from 26 May to 19 July

A flyer for a party at the Fridge hosted by Network 21, London’s only pirate TV station

displayImages.caption:
A flyer for the launch party of WBLS 88.5 FM
WBLS was started by rapper Derek B, and had a young Tim Westwood on its roster. But it was short lived, after it buckled under the combined pressure of a rival station breaking into its studio and smashing it up, and a raid from the DTI

displayImages.caption:
The Four Aces Club, Dalston, east London, 1986
Run by Newton Dunbar in a former theatre since the 1960s, the Four Aces incubated UK bass music pioneers such as the Ragga Twins and the Prodigy. It closed down in the late 1990s and the Victorian building was demolished in 2007

cards.title: Happy ever after? / Live the dream in a fairytale castle
cards.rawTitle: Live the dream in a fairytale castle

item.title: Live the dream in a fairytale castle
item.trailText: For £3.5m you can buy this 15th century chateau with 13 bedrooms, a caretaker’s cottage, tennis court and swimming pool
item.standFirst: For £3.5m you can buy this 15th century chateau with 13 bedrooms, a caretaker’s cottage, tennis court and swimming pool

displayImages.caption: Dating back to the 15th century, but with its current facade owing much to renovations carried out in the 19th century, this 13 bedroom partially restored French chateau is in Antigny, Vienne.  Photograph: Leggett Prestige
displayImages.cleanCaption: Dating back to the 15th century, but with its current facade owing much to renovations carried out in the 19th century, this 13 bedroom partially restored French chateau is in Antigny, Vienne.

displayImages.caption: Set in 80 acres of pasture and woodlands with over a kilometre of private river frontage, the chateau’s ornate gated entrance leads to a typically French styled garden. Included in the grounds are a caretaker’s cottage, stables and kennels, a swimming pool, a tennis court and a riverside lodge.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Set in 80 acres of pasture and woodlands with over a kilometre of private river frontage, the chateau’s ornate gated entrance leads to a typically French styled garden. Included in the grounds are a caretaker’s cottage, stables and kennels, a swimming pool, a tennis court and a riverside lodge.

displayImages.caption: One of the six bathrooms in the 15th-century French chateau.
displayImages.cleanCaption: One of the six bathrooms in the 15th-century French chateau.

displayImages.caption: The chateau combines original carved stone vaulted ceilings and a chapel with protected frescos with modern amenities like a fitted contemporary kitchen.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The chateau combines original carved stone vaulted ceilings and a chapel with protected frescos with modern amenities like a fitted contemporary kitchen.

displayImages.caption: The dining room with its original carved stone fireplace.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The dining room with its original carved stone fireplace.

displayImages.caption: The chateau is on the market for €4,750,000 (approximately £3,500,000) through agent Leggett Prestige.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The chateau is on the market for €4,750,000 (approximately £3,500,000) through agent Leggett Prestige.

cards.title: What do the people of Ireland think of the gay marriage referendum?
cards.rawTitle: What do the people of Ireland think of the gay marriage referendum?

item.title: Riyadh Khalaf's alternative look at the gay marriage referendum
item.trailText: Ahead of the same-sex marriage referendum in Ireland, Riyadh Khalaf asks Ireland whether tradition is a good thing, should it change and does it discriminate?
item.standFirst:
Today, Ireland will make history by becoming the first country in the world to put the issue of same-sex marriage to a public vote. Traditions change through the ages; mostly for the better. The people of Dublin give their opinion on bizarre ancient customs and the proposed changes to marriage equality.

Riyadh Khalaf's YouTube channel can be viewed here

stillImage.caption: 620x372 trailpic for Ireland's gay marriage referendum - video  Photograph: guardian.co.uk

cards.title: There’s A Girl In The Corner / Robert Smith covers the Twilight Sad
cards.rawTitle: Robert Smith covers the Twilight Sad

item.title: Listen to the Cure's Robert Smith cover the Twilight Sad
item.trailText: There’s A Girl In The Corner by Scottish group the Twilight Sad gets the ultimate endorsement with a cover by the Cure frontman. Listen to the exclusive here and tell us what you make of it
item.standFirst: There’s a Girl in the Corner by Scottish group the Twilight Sad gets the ultimate endorsement with a cover by the Cure frontman. Listen to the exclusive here and tell us what you make of it
item.body:
A few years ago, Stuart Braithwaite from Mogwai forwarded fellow Scottish post-rock group the Twilight Sad an email from the Cure’s Robert Smith, in which Smith said that he was a fan of the band.

“For as far back as I can remember, we have all been huge fans of the Cure, so reading that was obviously very mind blowing – although I was always slightly sceptical, thinking it was maybe Barry Burns from Mogwai, trying to pull some elaborate joke on us,” says Twilight Sad guitarist Andy MacFarlane.

The email was no prank. So the band endeavoured to squeeze a little more from this celebrity endorsement. After the release of their third album – No One Can Ever Know – the Twilight Sad were planning a remix version of the record with bands such as the Horrors, and Liars, and decided to email Smith to see if the project was something that would interest him. Which it did, but because of tour commitments, he couldn’t make it happen. So they tried again.

Related: Hear the Cure cover the Beatles on their first new recording for six years – exclusive

“After we recorded Nobody Wants to be Here and Nobody Wants to Leave I sent it to Robert to have a listen, and he said it was ‘BEAUTIFUL’. We wanted to do something special for the It Never Was the Same single, as it was going to be the last release from the album. I knew it was a pretty far-fetched idea, but thought I might as well chance my arm and ask Robert if he’d be up for covering one of our songs to feature as a double A-side. I couldn’t believe it when he replied saying he’d like to cover There’s a Girl in the Corner.

“He sent it over when we were playing San Francisco in March, and we listened to it over and over in the van, driving out after the gig. Hearing someone that we’ve all looked up to for so long sing and play one of our songs is definitely one of the most surreal moments that we’ve ever had.”

So there you have it. What do you think of the cover? What do you think Robert Smith’s email address is? Robsmith_69@hotmail.co.uk? Let us know in the comments.

kicker.title: There’s A Girl In The Corner

cards.title: Why Shamir's Ratchet is the one album you should hear this week
cards.rawTitle: Why Shamir's Ratchet is the one album you should hear this week

item.title: Why Shamir's Ratchet is the one album you should hear this week
item.trailText: The androgynous 20-year-old Las Vegas-based singer-songwriter has the voice and the music to drown out the hype. His debut album is a subtly-done disco and house infused delight, says Alexis Petridis - and the ballads might be the best part.
item.standFirst: The androgynous 20-year-old Las Vegas-based singer-songwriter has the voice and the music to drown out the hype. His debut album is a subtly-done disco and house infused delight, says Alexis Petridis - and the ballads might be the best part.

cards.title: Four-metre crocodile pulled from trap in Australia
cards.rawTitle: Four-metre crocodile pulled from trap in Australia

item.title: Four-metre crocodile pulled from trap in Northern Territory
item.trailText: A wildlife rescue team in Mandorah, Northern Territory, pull a four-metre crocodile from a trap having secured its mouth with rope
item.standFirst: A wildlife rescue team in Mandorah, Northern Territory, pull a four-metre crocodile from a trap having secured its mouth with rope. It was removed from the area to a place where it will not be a danger to the public. Saltwater crocodiles, also known as 'salties' can reach seven metres in size and weigh up to 1,000 kilograms

stillImage.caption: Saltwater crocodile pulled from trap in Mandorah, Northern Territory. 22 May 2015 Photograph: Reuters Photograph: Reuters
stillImage.cleanCaption: Saltwater crocodile pulled from trap in Mandorah, Northern Territory. 22 May 2015 Photograph: Reuters

cards.title: Amazing creatures / Top 10 new species of 2015

item.title: See the top 10 new species of 2015
item.trailText: A cartwheeling spider and a dinosaur dubbed the ‘chicken from hell’ are among the 10 most amazing creatures chosen by scientists from over 18,000 species new to science in the last year
item.standFirst: A cartwheeling spider and a dinosaur dubbed the ‘chicken from hell’ are among the 10 most amazing creatures chosen by scientists from over 18,000 species new to science in the last year. Find out more on the SUNY College of Environmental Science and Forestry website

displayImages.caption:
Feathered ‘Chicken from Hell’ dinosaur (Anzu wyliei) found in the US
With a mixture of bird and dinosaur features, Anzu wyliei is from a bird-like group of dinosaurs that lived in North America at the time of Trex and Triceratops. It may have had feathers but at 10 ft long (3.5 metres), five feet high and 600 pounds (200-300kg), this was no chicken Photograph: Mark A. Klingler/Carnegie Museum of Natural History/ESF
displayImages.credit: Mark A. Klingler/Carnegie Museum of Natural History/ESF
displayImages.altText: Life reconstruction of the new oviraptorosaurian dinosaur species Anzu wyliei in its ~66 million- year-old environment in western North America.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Feathered ‘Chicken from Hell’ dinosaur (Anzu wyliei) found in the US
With a mixture of bird and dinosaur features, Anzu wyliei is from a bird-like group of dinosaurs that lived in North America at the time of Trex and Triceratops. It may have had feathers but at 10 ft long (3.5 metres), five feet high and 600 pounds (200-300kg), this was no chicken
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mark A. Klingler/Carnegie Museum of Natural History/ESF

displayImages.caption:
Coral plant (Balanophora coralliformis) found in the Philippines
This parasitic plant, discovered and almost immediately considered endangered, has peculiar elongated, repeatedly branching, and rough-textured above-ground tubers. These are distinct from the more typical underground tubers of related species
Photograph: P.B. Pelser & J.F. Barcelona/ESF
displayImages.altText: Balanophora coralliformis: Branching aboveground tubers and young inflorescences of pistillate plant
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Coral plant (Balanophora coralliformis) found in the Philippines
This parasitic plant, discovered and almost immediately considered endangered, has peculiar elongated, repeatedly branching, and rough-textured above-ground tubers. These are distinct from the more typical underground tubers of related species

displayImages.caption:
Cartwheeling Spider (Cebrennus rechenbergi) found in Morocco
This agile arachnid from the desert cartwheels its way out of danger but rather than attempting to cartwheel away, the spider propels itself toward the source of the threat. In the barren sand dunes where it lives, running away can prove pointless because there is no place to hide. Even before the spider had been officially named, its behaviour inspired a biomimetic robot that can similarly walk or roll Photograph: Prof. Dr. Ingo Rechenberg/Technical University Berlin/ESF
displayImages.credit: Prof. Dr. Ingo Rechenberg/Technical University Berlin/ESF
displayImages.altText: Cebrennus rechenbergi: Cartwheeling spider, Erg Chebbi, Morocco
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Cartwheeling Spider (Cebrennus rechenbergi) found in Morocco
This agile arachnid from the desert cartwheels its way out of danger but rather than attempting to cartwheel away, the spider propels itself toward the source of the threat. In the barren sand dunes where it lives, running away can prove pointless because there is no place to hide. Even before the spider had been officially named, its behaviour inspired a biomimetic robot that can similarly walk or roll
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Prof. Dr. Ingo Rechenberg/Technical University Berlin/ESF

displayImages.caption: The X-Phyla (Dendrogramma enigmatica) from Australia These mysterious newcomers, and a second new species, D. discoids, are multi-cellular animals that look like mushrooms, with a mouth at the end of the “stem” and the other end in the form of a flattened disc. The best information suggests that they are related to the phylum Cnidaria (jellyfish, corals, sea anemones and hydras) or Ctenophora (comb jellies) or both, but they could be an entirely new phylum. It was found on the sea floor, at a depth of about 3,200 ft (1,000 meters) and the stalk measures less than 8 mm long. Photograph: Jørgen Olesen/ESF
displayImages.altText: Dendrogramma enigmatica: lateral and aboral views. Photographs taken after shrinkage
displayImages.cleanCaption: The X-Phyla (Dendrogramma enigmatica) from Australia These mysterious newcomers, and a second new species, D. discoids, are multi-cellular animals that look like mushrooms, with a mouth at the end of the “stem” and the other end in the form of a flattened disc. The best information suggests that they are related to the phylum Cnidaria (jellyfish, corals, sea anemones and hydras) or Ctenophora (comb jellies) or both, but they could be an entirely new phylum. It was found on the sea floor, at a depth of about 3,200 ft (1,000 meters) and the stalk measures less than 8 mm long.

displayImages.caption:
Bone house wasp (Deuteragenia ossarium) found in South East China
At about a half-inch (15mm) in length this wasp has a unique way to protect its offspring. It constructs nests in hollow stems with several cells, each separated by soil walls. The wasp kills and deposits one spider in each cell to provide nourishment for her developing young. But she fills the final or vestibule cell, not with a spider but with as many as 13 bodies of dead ants, thus creating a chemical barrier to the nest. This is the first animal known to take this approach to securing the front door to a nest Photograph: Michael Staab/ESF
displayImages.altText: Deuteragenia ossarium: A female of Deuteragenia ossarium in its natural ecosystem in South East China
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Bone house wasp (Deuteragenia ossarium) found in South East China
At about a half-inch (15mm) in length this wasp has a unique way to protect its offspring. It constructs nests in hollow stems with several cells, each separated by soil walls. The wasp kills and deposits one spider in each cell to provide nourishment for her developing young. But she fills the final or vestibule cell, not with a spider but with as many as 13 bodies of dead ants, thus creating a chemical barrier to the nest. This is the first animal known to take this approach to securing the front door to a nest

displayImages.caption:
Indonesian Frog (Limnonectes larvaepartus) found in Indonesia
The newest species of fanged frog is unlike other frogs because it gives birth to tadpoles that are deposited in pools of water. Fewer than a dozen of the world’s 6,455 frog species have internal fertilisation and all except this new species lay fertilised eggs or give birth to tiny froglets. The species, about 1.5 inches long (40mm), is found on Sulawesi Island and the extent of its range is not yet known Photograph: Jimmy A. McGuire/ESF
displayImages.altText: Limnonectes larvaepartus: male (left) and female (right) photographed in the field on Sulawesi
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Indonesian Frog (Limnonectes larvaepartus) found in Indonesia
The newest species of fanged frog is unlike other frogs because it gives birth to tadpoles that are deposited in pools of water. Fewer than a dozen of the world’s 6,455 frog species have internal fertilisation and all except this new species lay fertilised eggs or give birth to tiny froglets. The species, about 1.5 inches long (40mm), is found on Sulawesi Island and the extent of its range is not yet known

displayImages.caption:
Walking Stick (Phryganistria tamdaoensis) found in Vietnam
While this new stick insect is not the world’s longest, it belongs to a family known as giant sticks. At 9 inches in length it is compelling evidence that, in spite of their size, more giant sticks remain to be discovered and our knowledge of these masters of camouflage is far from complete. This giant stick is common in the town of Tam Dao, yet it escaped notice until now. If you would like to see one of these big bugs up close, living specimens are on display at the Royal Belgian Institute of Natural Sciences in Brussels Photograph: Bruno Kneubühler/ESF
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Walking Stick (Phryganistria tamdaoensis) found in Vietnam
While this new stick insect is not the world’s longest, it belongs to a family known as giant sticks. At 9 inches in length it is compelling evidence that, in spite of their size, more giant sticks remain to be discovered and our knowledge of these masters of camouflage is far from complete. This giant stick is common in the town of Tam Dao, yet it escaped notice until now. If you would like to see one of these big bugs up close, living specimens are on display at the Royal Belgian Institute of Natural Sciences in Brussels

displayImages.caption:
Sea Slug (Phyllodesmium acanthorhinum) found in Japan
This sea slug is a “missing link” between sea slugs that feed on hydroids and those specialising on corals. Gastropods do not get more photogenic than sea slugs whose graceful lines and vivid coloration make them beauties of the deep. This new species contributed to a better understanding of the origin of an unusual symbiosis in other species of the genus Photograph: ESF
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Sea Slug (Phyllodesmium acanthorhinum) found in Japan
This sea slug is a “missing link” between sea slugs that feed on hydroids and those specialising on corals. Gastropods do not get more photogenic than sea slugs whose graceful lines and vivid coloration make them beauties of the deep. This new species contributed to a better understanding of the origin of an unusual symbiosis in other species of the genus

displayImages.caption:
Bromeliad (Tillandsia religiosa) found in Mexico
During Christmas celebrations in Mexico, elaborate altar scenes or “nacimientos” depicting the birth of Christ are assembled by villagers. In Sierra de Tepoztlán, Tlayacapan, San José de los Laureles, and Tepoztlán, a beautiful bromeliad plant is frequently incorporated in the display. The plant turned out to be new to science. Tillandsia religiosa, with its rose-colored spikes and flat green leaves, can be found growing up to five feet tall (1.5m) in rocky habitat in northern regions of Morelos, Mexico Photograph: A. Espejo/ESF
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Bromeliad (Tillandsia religiosa) found in Mexico
During Christmas celebrations in Mexico, elaborate altar scenes or “nacimientos” depicting the birth of Christ are assembled by villagers. In Sierra de Tepoztlán, Tlayacapan, San José de los Laureles, and Tepoztlán, a beautiful bromeliad plant is frequently incorporated in the display. The plant turned out to be new to science. Tillandsia religiosa, with its rose-colored spikes and flat green leaves, can be found growing up to five feet tall (1.5m) in rocky habitat in northern regions of Morelos, Mexico

displayImages.caption:
Pufferfish (Torquigener albomaculosus) found in Japan
Scientists recently solved a 20-year-old mystery under the sea and discovered a new fish. Intricate ‘crop circles’ with geometric designs about six feet (2 meters) in diameter were found on the seafloor off the coast of Amami-Ōshima Island. They turn out to be the work of this new species of pufferfish. Males construct these circles as spawning nests by swimming and wriggling in the seafloor sand Photograph: Yoji Okata/ESF
displayImages.altText: Torquigener albomaculosus: A male (right) biting on the left cheek of a female (left) while they were spawning
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Pufferfish (Torquigener albomaculosus) found in Japan
Scientists recently solved a 20-year-old mystery under the sea and discovered a new fish. Intricate ‘crop circles’ with geometric designs about six feet (2 meters) in diameter were found on the seafloor off the coast of Amami-Ōshima Island. They turn out to be the work of this new species of pufferfish. Males construct these circles as spawning nests by swimming and wriggling in the seafloor sand

displayImages.caption: The nests, used only once, are made to attract females. The nests have double edges and radiating troughs in a spoke-like geometry. The design isn’t just for show. Scientists discovered the ridges and grooves of the circle serve to minimise ocean current at the centre of the nest. This protects the eggs from the turbulent waters and possibly predators too Photograph: Yoji Okata/ESF
displayImages.altText: A spawning nest (mystery circle) of Torquigener albomaculosus found at 26m depth on a sandy bottom along the south coast of Amami-Oshima Island in the Ryukyu Islands
displayImages.cleanCaption: The nests, used only once, are made to attract females. The nests have double edges and radiating troughs in a spoke-like geometry. The design isn’t just for show. Scientists discovered the ridges and grooves of the circle serve to minimise ocean current at the centre of the nest. This protects the eggs from the turbulent waters and possibly predators too
